sect3.title: Configuration Information
sect3.para: There are several default configurations file available in /usr/share/mysql which you can use.
We can now install a database and change the ownership to the unpriviledged user and group.
Further configuration requires that the mysql server be running:
A default installation, does not setup a password for the administrator. So here we will login and set one. We strongly suggest changing 'new-password' to your own.

userinput.command:
mysql -uroot mysql Welcome to the MySQL monitor. Commands end with ; or \g. Your MySQL connection id is 2 to server version: 3.23.51-log
Type 'help;' or '\h' for help. Type '\c' to clear the buffer.
mysql> UPDATE user SET password=password('new-password') WHERE user='root'; Query OK, 2 rows affected (0.00 sec) Rows matched: 2 Changed: 2 Warnings: 0
mysql> FLUSH PRIVILEGES; Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)
mysql> EXIT; bye

sect3.para: Now that we are done with the configuration of the server, we can shut it down.

sect4.title: MySQL init.d script
sect4.para: To automate the running of MySQL, use the following command to create the init.d script:
Create the symbolic links to this file in the relevant rc.d directory with the following commands:

userinput.command: cd /etc/rc.d/init.d && ln -sf ../init.d/mysql ../rc0.d/K26mysql && ln -sf ../init.d/mysql ../rc1.d/K26mysql && ln -sf ../init.d/mysql ../rc2.d/K26mysql && ln -sf ../init.d/mysql ../rc3.d/S34mysql && ln -sf ../init.d/mysql ../rc4.d/S34mysql && ln -sf ../init.d/mysql ../rc5.d/S34mysql && ln -sf ../init.d/mysql ../rc6.d/K26mysql
